content.raw:
> Ideally, systems shouldn't have an internal state at all.

In theory it would be great if this could be the case, but it’s not practical or even desirable, if only for performance considerations.

Taking physics as a straightforward example, every physics engine will have its own way of storing, manipulating, and caching data about physics, about models, and about the environment. It’s not possible for a physics system to lack an internal state.

`ign-physics` borrows some of the useful aspects of the ECS concept for the sake of being an extremely lightweight abstraction layer, but `ign-physics` handles state in the opposite way of `ign-gazebo`. The role of `ign-gazebo` is essentially to shovel some generic representations of state from one system to another. `ign-physics` does the opposite: It does not maintain _any_ concept of state itself, and instead allows the underlying physics engine to manage its own state in whatever way it chooses. That design wouldn't work for `ign-gazebo` because `ign-gazebo` needs to be more like a middleware between systems instead of a wrapper around one system.

For stateful systems \(which I strongly believe we cannot avoid and should not try to\), instead of communicating information about the current state, we’ll want to communicate changes about all changes to state since the last update.

‌

> while minimizing the costs of moving state mentioned above.

If we can have some concept of a delta between sequential states and have a way for the physics system to consume that delta, we shouldn’t have any trouble.

content.raw:
> I think this should also be true for physics, because we will inevitably run into cases where things will need to be moved, since we can't control how performers will interact (or do we want to?). Do you agree with this statement? Maybe there's something I'm missing.

I think it would be great if we didn't have to move any system at all including physics. But,If I recall correctly from a conversation with @scpeters, it is very difficult to perform a stable physics simulation of two interacting (colliding) performers in two separate physics engine instances. So physics has to be moved out of necessity.

Regarding the cost of moving a system, I'd add:

* Added complexity for system authors as they have to make sure all their state is kept in the ECS. And if an author neglects to do this, that system won't function properly when moved. We'll then have to deal with systems that are movable and those that are not. I don't know if there's a way to find out without inspecting the code.
* Risk of instability when transport nodes get destroyed and recreated, especially if this happens while the node is actively sending/receiving a message.

Overall, in my opinion, it would be better if we kept the systems that have to be moved to a small set so that only a few system authors have to deal with it.

> A simulation runner would be aware of the level(s) the performer is in and would have loaded all the entities accordingly

But isn't this also true for the physics?

> Any system that needs ign-rendering has all it needs to create a render without having to be moved to another runner

I think this should also be true for physics, because we will inevitably run into cases where things will need to be moved, since we can't control how performers will interact (or do we want to?). Do you agree with this statement? Maybe there's something I'm missing.

For me, the question is about the **cost** of moving a system, which may come down to:

* The total set of components needed to fully describe internal state
* The effort to destroy / create entities and components

I believe physics may need to use a larger set of components to fully describe its full internal state (pose, velocity, acceleration...), while rendering mainly just needs pose most of the time. But in both cases, there are other components which will need to be synced as well, but will be less common, such as mass changes for physics and material changes for rendering.

As for the effort, from what I've understood so far regarding ign-physics, this may be the big issue? Is it so much easier to create / destroy entities in rendering than in physics?

> If another performer happens to be in the same level and it is far enough away that the two performers aren't interacting, the runner would load it without simulating its physics

Yeah, and if we go with level-centered runners for physics, we may need different level sizes for physics and rendering.

Agreed.

> Will we offer interfaces similar to model/world plugins that offer a physics interface? Visual plugins that offer an interface to ign-rendering? 

Good questions. Beside having a similar API to model/world plugins, would such interfaces give direct access to ign-physics or ign-rendering to users or indirect access through the ECS?  Going through the ECS would make it easier to transparently distribute the simulation, but it might cost us in performance. For vision sensors on the performer, each sensor will need to render its own view any way so it can stay in the original runner. I don't know if this duplication can be avoided.

content.raw:
> How do we handle systems that communicate with clients outside of ign-gazebo (e.g. ROS nodes)?

I think this is a valid use case, but our immediate priority is supporting clients which use `ign-transport`, which is not limited to be used inside `ign-gazebo`. The current idea is that the ROS integration will be made by a bridge which can run in its own process and relays messages and services from ign to ROS and back. I'll add a section to the document about this.

> Systems that are "distributable" would only use ign-transport to communicate with other systems.

In my mind, the way systems would "communicate" would be either through the ECS (by modifying components) or through events. I was thinking of ign-transport as the interface to the outside of ign-gazebo. Internally, it will be used for synchronizing runners, but I think that system developers shouldn't worry about that. Let me know if I misunderstood what you meant.

> This is assuming ign-transport supports moving nodes as you mentioned earlier.

Just a clarification, a node wouldn't be *moved*, it would be destroyed and a new node publishing the same topics would be created.

 > When a distributable system needs to communicate outside ign-transport, the author of the system would need to write a non-distributable system to relay messages between ign-transport and the external communication scheme. 

Agreed, I think that if someone wants to use a different transport inside a system, they will need to figure it out themselves. If this becomes an important use case, I think we can revisit and try to offer a convenient interface.

> have systems that are "distributable" and systems that are not (i.e, stay on the primary)

Do you think there's any special interface these systems would need to have, or would it be enough to load them in the correct place in the SDF?

> Options:

I vote for option 2, where plugins are able to register their custom components and let the ECS handle serialization. It feels to me that doing anything other than that means we'd have to support 2 state synchronization mechanisms, the ECS and the other one.

content.raw: Having runners associated with performers rather than levels has the advantage that most systems don't have to be moved from one runner to another. In the case of interacting performers, only physics would need to be "moved". In that scenario the runner that just received the new performer would send all the data back to the original owner of the performer. The original owner updates it's components as though it ran its own physics. Thus, the whole performer transfer between the runners would be completely transparent to all the systems in the original runner (except physics, of course).

content.raw:
How do we handle systems that communicate with clients outside of ign-gazebo (e.g. ROS nodes)? I don't think it would be possible to move the system to another runner if that runner could be on another machine. 

This might have already been mentioned by @carromj, but one possibility would be to have systems that are "distributable" and systems that are not (i.e, stay on the primary). Systems that are "distributable" would only use ign-transport to communicate with other systems. This is assuming ign-transport supports moving nodes as you mentioned earlier. When a distributable system needs to communicate outside ign-transport, the author of the system would need to write a non-distributable system to relay messages between ign-transport and the external communication scheme. 

Another issue is how the internal state of a system is moved between runners. For example, a PID controller system would need to keep track of past errors. Options:
  
  * Require such systems to provide their own state serialization and passed the serialized state as the initial state when loading the system in the new runner.
  * Require systems to store their state as components of an entity that represents the system and rely on component serialization.
  * Provide a way (maybe using events) for a system being moved to send data to its destination and leave the details to the system author.

> Is each secondary runner runner associated with a level in the world (as opposed to a performer)?

When multiple performers are in the same level, they're necessarily in the same runner.

An alternative we discussed was to only move performers to the same runner when they're about to collide, which is essentially like smaller levels that move around each performer (the performer's window). My personal feeling is that having one extra layer beyond levels (the windows) will add much complexity with little gain. In any case we will have situations when many performers must be in the same runner.

I think there can be multiple levels simulated in the same runner, such as in the single performer example below. I think we could make this configurable, but I'm not clear on what the parameters could be.

So in the situation when all robots start in the same level, the simulation starts slow, with a single runner simulating them all. Then as robots move to different levels, new runners are spun up and levels are spread across them.

(Note none of this is written in stone, this is just my current suggestion)

Is each secondary runner runner associated with a level in the world (as opposed to a performer)?

When multiple performers are in the same level, they're necessarily in the same runner.

An alternative we discussed was to only move performers to the same runner when they're about to collide, which is essentially like smaller levels that move around each performer (the performer's window). My personal feeling is that having one extra layer beyond levels (the windows) will add much complexity with little gain. In any case we will have situations when many performers must be in the same runner.

I think there can be multiple levels simulated in the same runner, such as in the single performer example below. I think we could make this configurable, but I'm not clear on what the parameters could be.

So in the situation when all robots start in the same level, the simulation starts slow, with a single runner simulating them all. Then as robots move to different levels, new runners are spun up and levels are spread across them.
